Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Maintain laboratory equipment and ensure safety protocols are followed
Situation2: The routine maintenance checklist is coming up soon, but no malfunctions have been noted.
Story: My phone buzzes insistently in my pocket as I finish logging the last set of data for the day. I know it’s my mother—she always texts around this time, wanting to hear about my day, asking for little details about my lunch or the weather. I usually reply right away, sending her a quick photo or a reassuring message. But today, the lab feels different. The maintenance checklist is due soon, and even though everything seems fine, I can’t shake the responsibility of double-checking every piece of equipment. Safety protocols are strict, and as the lead scientist, I’m expected to set the standard. My team relies on me to keep things running smoothly, and any oversight could have serious consequences. I glance at my phone again, feeling the weight of my mother’s expectations—her need for connection, her worry if I don’t respond quickly. At the same time, the silent hum of the lab reminds me of my duty here. I stand frozen, torn between the comfort of my mother’s familiar words and the pressing obligation to ensure the lab’s safety, my heart pulled in two directions.
